titleInfo.title: Utilizing Universal Screening to Assess Effectiveness of Targeted Social and Emotional Learning Curriculums

name.namePart: College of Education, Health, and Human Sciences
Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies

mods:mods.abstract: The purpose of this study was to explore whether a targeted Social and Emotional Learning (SEL) program, Classroom Champions, would close gaps in SEL skill areas identified by a student universal screener. This study specifically examined the skill areas of persistence, engagement, and optimism. The first research question examined the levels of student persistence, engagement, and optimism in comparison and intervention groups before and after program implementation. The second research question examined the relationship between student participation in Classroom Champions and student growth in the areas of persistence, engagement, and optimism. The third research question examined how growth in the areas of persistence, engagement, and optimism among intervention group participants differed by gender. Participants in both the intervention (n = 215) and comparison group (n = 545) were in grades 6-12. Participants were given a universal screener prior to SEL curriculum to obtain baseline scores for persistence, engagement, and optimism. The screener was administered again after completion of instructional delivery to obtain post-test scores. Data analysis was completed with the use of paired sample t-tests, independent sample t-tests, simple linear regression, and multiple regression. Findings showed that both the intervention and comparison group saw statistically significant differences in pre- and post-test scores in the area of engagement. There was a statistically significant change score in the area of persistence for the intervention group; however, analysis of pre-test means showed that the intervention group started out significantly lower than the comparison group in this area. There were no statistically significant findings related to gender. In conclusion, although there were some statistically significant findings, there were no conclusive results that the targeted SEL curriculum was able to close the identified SEL skill gaps.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Educational Leadership and Policy Studies in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Education.
Stephanie Zuilkowski, Professor Directing Dissertation; Amy Guerette, University Representative; Erica Harbatkin, Committee Member; Stacey Rutledge, Committee Member.
